sen.j: 後鳥羽天皇（ごとばてんのう、治承4年7月14日（1180年8月6日） - 延応元年2月22日（1239年3月28日）； 在位：寿永2年（1183年）8月20日 - 建久9年（1198年）1月11日）は、平安時代末期から鎌倉時代初期にかけて在位した第82代天皇。
sen.e: Emperor GOTOBA (August 6th, 1180 - 28th March 1239) (His reign was 20th August, 1183 - 11th January, 1198) was the 82nd Emperor who was in power during the end of Heian Period to early Kamakura Period.
sen.cmt: 平安時代 Heian Period, 鎌倉時代 Kamakura Period 研究社新和英大辞典

Emperor Go-Toba (August 6, 1180 - March 28, 1239) (his reign was August 20, 1183 - January 11, 1198) was the eighty-second Emperor, being in power during the end of the Heian period to the early Kamakura period.

Because Emperor Go-Toba was enthroned before the abdication of Emperor Antoku, there was an overlapping period of two years in which there were two emperors (between 1183 and 1185), until the Taira clan disappeared.

Since Emperor Antoku took three sacred emblems of the Imperial Family with him, together with the Taira clan, in their absence there was an emergency plan: the Cloistered Emperor Go-Shirakawa ordered Emperor Go-Toba to succeed to the Imperial Throne as a command from a former Emperor.

sen.e: After the monk-Emperor Go-Shirakawa died, MINAMOTO no Yoritomo was ordered to became a Barbarian Subduing Generalissimo with Kanpaku/chief adviser to the Emperor, Kanezane KUJO's help, Yoritomo started Japan's feudal government in Kamakura. (later call as Kamakura government)

sen.e: Following the death of the monk-Emperor Go-Shirakawa, MINAMOTO no Yoritomo was ordered to became a "barbarian subduing generalissimo" with the help of the kanpaku (chief adviser) to the Emperor, Kanezane KUJO; Yoritomo started Japan's feudal government in Kamakura (later known as the Kamakura government).

Following the death of the Cloistered Emperor Go-Shirakawa, MINAMOTO no Yoritomo was ordered to become Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") with the help of the kanpaku (chief adviser) to the Emperor, Kanezane KUJO; Yoritomo started Japan's feudal government in Kamakura (later known as the Kamakura government).

sen.j: 同7年（1196年）、源通親の娘に皇子が産まれた事で政変が起こり、九条兼実の勢力は朝廷から一掃され、兼実の娘・九条任子も中宮の位を奪われ宮中から追われた。
sen.e: In 1196, after MINAMOTO no Michichika had a female child, it caused a political change, Kanezane KUJO's people were forced to leave from the Imperial Palace, even his daughter, Ninshi KUJO lost her position of the second consort of the Emperor and had to leave the Palace.

In 1196, after MINAMOTO no Michichika's daughter had a son, it caused a political change and Kanezane KUJO's people were forced to leave the Imperial Palace; even his daughter, Ninshi KUJO, lost her position as the second consort of the Emperor and had to leave.

sen.j: 建久9年（1198年）1月11日、土御門天皇に譲位し、以後、土御門、順徳天皇、仲恭天皇と承久三年（1221年）まで、3代23年間に渡り太上天皇として院政を敷く。
sen.e: 11th January, 1198, Emperor Tsuchimikado took over the Imperial Throne, Emperor GOTOBA continued to run his cloister government as an ex-emperor for twenty three years until 1221, three generations started from Emperor TSUCHIMIKADO, Emperor JUNTOKU and Emperor CHUKYU.
sen.cmt: 土御門天皇 Emperor Tsuchimikado, 順徳天皇 Emperor JUNTOKU, 仲恭天皇 Emperor CHUKYU, 太上天皇 an ex-emperor
sen.e: On January 11, 1198, Emperor Tsuchimikado took over the Imperial Throne, but Emperor GOTOBA continued to run his cloister government as an ex-emperor for 23 years until 1221, spanning three generations starting from Emperor TSUCHIMIKADO to Emperor JUNTOKU and Emperor CHUKYU.

On January 11, 1198, Emperor Tsuchimikado took over the Imperial Throne, but Emperor Go-Toba continued to run his cloister government as a retired emperor for 23 years until 1221, spanning three generations starting from Emperor Tsuchimikado and continuing to Emperor Juntoku and Emperor Chukyo.
sen.cmt: GOTOBA→Go-TobaTSUCHIMIKADO→TsuchimikadoJUNTOKU→JuntokuCHUKYU→Chukyo"an ex-emperor"→"a retired emperor"に変更しました。

sen.j: 上皇になると殿上人を整理（旧来は天皇在位中の殿上人はそのまま院の殿上人となる慣例であった）して院政機構の改革を行うなどの積極的な政策を採って、台頭する鎌倉幕府に対しても強硬的な路線を採った。
sen.e: After he became ex-emperor, he took an active policy to organized a (high-ranking) courtier allowed into the Imperial Palace;a court noble (traditionaly those people who served the Emperor would stay with the ex-emperor) to reform the system of the cloister government, he was ready to take forceful action against Kamakura Government who started to became conspicuous.

sen.e: Once he became the ex-emperor, he made an active effort to become a (high-ranking) courtier allowed into the Imperial Palace, as a court noble (traditionally, people who served the Emperor would stay with him after his reign) in order to reform the system of the cloister government; he was ready to take forceful action against the Kamakura government, which had started to behave conspicuously.

Once he became the retired emperor, he made an active effort to become a (high-ranking) courtier allowed into the Imperial Palace, as a court noble (traditionally, people who served an emperor would stay with him after his reign) in order to reform the system of the cloister government; he was ready to take forceful action against the Kamakura government, which had started to behave conspicuously.
sen.cmt: "ex-emperor"→"retired emperor"に変更しました。"the Emperor"→"an emperor"に変更しました。

tit.cmt: 承久の乱 The Jokyu war

sen.j: 承久3年（1221年）5月14日、後鳥羽上皇は、時の執権北条義時追討の院宣を出し、畿内・近国の兵を召集して承久の乱を起こしたが、幕府の大軍に完敗。
sen.e: On 14 May, 1221, Emperor GOTOBA gave an official document to expel a Regent, Yoshitoki HOJO from the government, he gathered the solders near Kyoto and caused the Jokyu War, however he was defeated badly by the Kamakura Government.

sen.e: On May 14, 1221, Emperor GOTOBA gave an official document to expel the regent Yoshitoki HOJO from the government; he gathered the solders near Kyoto and triggered the Jokyu War, but he was severely beaten by the Kamakura government.

On May 14, 1221, the Retired Emperor Go-Toba gave an official document to expel the regent Yoshitoki HOJO from the government; he gathered the solders near Kyoto and triggered the Jokyu War, but he was severely beaten by the Kamakura government.

sen.j: わずか2ヶ月あとの7月9日、19万の大軍を率いて上京した義時の嫡男北条泰時によって、後鳥羽上皇は隠岐島（隠岐国海士郡の中ノ島、現海士町）に配流された。
sen.e: Just after two months from this incident, on 9th July, Yoshitoki's son, Yasutoki HOJO came to Kyoto with nineteen hundred-thousands solders and ex-Emperor GOTOBA was sentenced to deportation sent to Oki no-shima Island (Naka no shima, Ama County, Oki Province, current Ama cho-town)

sen.e: Slightly more than two months after the incident, on July 9, Yoshitoki's son Yasutoki HOJO came to Kyoto with 1,900 solders; subsequently, ex-Emperor GOTOBA was sentenced to deportation and sent to Oki no-shima Island (Naka no shima, Ama County, Oki Province, the current Ama-cho Town).

Slightly more than two months after the incident, on July 9, Yoshitoki's son Yasutoki HOJO came to Kyoto with 190,000 solders; subsequently, the Retired Emperor Go-Toba was sentenced to deportation and sent to Oki no-shima Island (Naka no shima, Ama County, Oki Province, the present-day Ama-cho Town).

sen.j: 父の倒幕計画に協力した順徳上皇は佐渡島に流され、関与しなかった土御門上皇も自ら望んで土佐国に遷った。
sen.e: Emperor JUNTOKU helped his father to defeat Kamakura Government, he was then sent to Sado ga-shima Island, the Emperor TSUCHIMIKADO also went to Tosa Province with his own will although he was not involved in the same incident.

Emperor Juntoku helped his father defeat the Kamakura government, but he was then sent to Sado ga-shima Island; the Emperor Tsuchimikado also went to Tosa Province by his own will, although he was not involved in the incident.

sen.j: さらに、在位わずか3ヶ月足らずの幼帝仲恭天皇（当時四歳）も廃され、代わりに高倉院の孫、後堀河天皇が皇位に推挙され、その父守貞親王が院政を執ることになった。
sen.e: Furthermore, the young Emperor CHUKYO who enthroned for three months (he was four years old) was got rid of, instead TAKURA-in's grandchild, Emperor HORIKAWA was recommended to succeed the Imperial Thorne, his father Prince MORISADA took control of the cloister government.

sen.e: Furthermore, the young Emperor CHUKYO, who was enthroned for three months (he was four years old) was gotten rid of, and instead TAKURA-in's grandchild (the future Emperor HORIKAWA) was recommended to succeed the Imperial Throne, and his father, Prince MORISADA, took control of the cloister government.

Furthermore, the young Emperor Chukyo, who was enthroned for three months (he was four years old) was removed, and instead Takakura-in's grandchild (the future Emperor Horikawa) was recommended to succeed the Imperial Throne, and his father, Prince Morisada, took control of the cloister government.

sen.j: 隠岐に流される直前に出家して法皇となった後鳥羽上皇は、四条天皇代の延応元年（1239年）2月20日、配所にて崩御。

GOTOBA (no)-in was one of the greatest, most outstanding poets of the Medieval period; his poems had an enormous impact on the later periods.
Go-Toba (no)-in was one of the greatest, most outstanding poets of the Medieval period; his poems had an enormous impact on the later periods.

sen.j: 院がいつごろから歌作に興味を持ちはじめたかは分明ではないが、通説では建久9年（1198年）一月の譲位、ならびに同8月の熊野行幸以降急速に和歌に志すようになり、正治元年（1199年）以降盛んに歌会・歌合などを行うようになった。
sen.e: It is unknown when GOTOBA-in started having interests in making poems, it is generally said he started when he abdicated the throne in January 1198, also in the same year of August, he suddenly started making poems after the imperial visit to Kumano, in 1199 he often opened poem competition// poetry party or poetry contest.

sen.e: It is unknown when GOTOBA-in acquired an interest in poetry, but generally it is said that he started when he abdicated the throne in January 1198; also, in August of that year he suddenly started writing poems after the Imperial visit to Kumano, and in 1199 he often opened a poetry competition (a poetry party or poetry contest).

It is unknown when Go-Toba-in acquired an interest in poetry, but generally it is said that he started when he abdicated the throne in January 1198; also, in August of that year he suddenly started writing poems after the imperial visit to Kumano, and in 1199 he often opened poetry competitions (poetry parties or contests).

Go-Toba-in admired FUJIWARA no Sadaie's (Teika) style of poetry writing, the latter being the main person of the Kujo Family in the world of tanka poetry; the tanka circle, being similar to 新儀非拠達磨歌 at that time, was the stylistic manner of praising something and criticizing at the same time.

sen.j: 正治2年（1200年）7月に主宰した正治初度百首和歌においては、式子内親王、九条良経、藤原俊成、慈円、寂蓮、藤原定家、藤原家隆ら、九条家歌壇・御子左家系の歌人に詠進を求めている。
sen.e: In July 1200, when Shoji Shodo Hyakushu Waka was held, Go-Toba-in invited the poets of the Kujo Family, representing the world of tanka poetry, along with members of the tanka circle and the Mikohidari Family, such as Princess Shikishi (Shokushi), Yoshitsune KUJO, FUJIWARA no Shunzei (Toshinari), Jien, Jakuren, FUJIWARA no Sadaie (Teika) and FUJIWARA no Ietaka to send poems to the Imperial Palace or temples.
